jsx.core
Class NumberLikes

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      jsx.core.NumberLikes

public final class NumberLikes
extends Disposable

A utility class providing basic number operations with its static methods.

Users are encouraged to use the utilities provided by this class instead of the opaque methods of NumberLike, JsNumber or Value.Number in consideration of the reuse benefit for re-compilation results.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org

Method Detail

toExponential

public static final java.lang.String toExponential(NumberLike<?> n)

Converts the current number to a string using exponential notation.

Parameters:
n - The current number.
Returns:
A string representation of the current number, in exponential notation. The fractional part of the number is rounded, or padded with zeros, as necessary, so that it has the specified length.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked on an instance that is not a number. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
toExponential(js.NumberLike, Object), toFixed(js.NumberLike), toFixed(js.NumberLike, Object), toLocaleString(js.NumberLike), toPrecision(js.NumberLike), toPrecision(js.NumberLike, Object), toString(js.NumberLike), toString(js.NumberLike, Object), NumberLike.toExponential()

toExponential

public static final java.lang.String toExponential(NumberLike<?> n,
                                                   java.lang.Object digits)

Converts the current number to a string using exponential notation with the specified number of digits after the decimal place.

Parameters:
n - The current number.
digits - The number of digits that appears after the decimal point. This may be a value between 0 and 20, inclusive, and implementations may optionally support a larger range of values. If this argument is undefined, as many digits as necessary are used.
Returns:
A string representation of the current number, in exponential notation, with one digit before the decimal place and digits digits after the decimal place. The fractional part of the number is rounded, or padded with zeros, as necessary, so that it has the specified length.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a RangeError if digits is too small or too large. See Js.err(Object) and JsRangeError for JS Simulation. Values between 0 and 20, inclusive, will not cause a RangeError. Implementations are allowed to support larger and smaller values as well.
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked on an instance that is not a number. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
toExponential(js.NumberLike), toFixed(js.NumberLike), toFixed(js.NumberLike, Object), toLocaleString(js.NumberLike), toPrecision(js.NumberLike), toPrecision(js.NumberLike, Object), toString(js.NumberLike), toString(js.NumberLike, Object), NumberLike.toExponential(Object)

Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a RangeError if digits is too small or too large. See Js.err(Object) and JsRangeError for JS Simulation. Values between 0 and 20, inclusive, will not cause a RangeError. Implementations are allowed to support larger and smaller values as well.

toFixed

public static final java.lang.String toFixed(NumberLike<?> n)

Converts the current number to a string without digits after the decimal place.

Parameters:
n - The current number.
Returns:
A string representation of the current number that does not use exponential notation and has no digits after the decimal place. The number is rounded if necessary. If the current number is greater than 1e+21, this method simply calls DateLike.toString() and returns a string in exponential notation.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked on an instance that is not a number. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
toFixed(js.NumberLike, Object), toExponential(js.NumberLike), toExponential(js.NumberLike, Object), toLocaleString(js.NumberLike), toPrecision(js.NumberLike), toPrecision(js.NumberLike, Object), toString(js.NumberLike), toString(js.NumberLike, Object), NumberLike.toFixed()

toFixed

public static final java.lang.String toFixed(NumberLike<?> n,
                                             java.lang.Object digits)

Converts the current number to a string that contains a specified number of digits after the decimal place.

Parameters:
n - The current number.
digits - The number of digits to appear after the decimal point; this may be a value between 0 and 20, inclusive, and implementations may optionally support a larger range of values. If this argument is undefined, it is treated as 0.
Returns:
A string representation of the current number that does not use exponential notation and has exactly digits digits after the decimal place. The number is rounded if necessary, and the fractional part is padded with zeros if necessary so that it has the specified length. If the current number is greater than 1e+21, this method simply calls NumberLike.toString() and returns a string in exponential notation.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a RangeError if digits is too small or too large. See Js.err(Object) and JsRangeError for JS Simulation. Values between 0 and 20, inclusive, will not cause a RangeError. Implementations are allowed to support larger and smaller values as well.
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked on an instance that is not a number. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
toFixed(js.NumberLike), toExponential(js.NumberLike), toExponential(js.NumberLike, Object), toLocaleString(js.NumberLike), toPrecision(js.NumberLike), toPrecision(js.NumberLike, Object), toString(js.NumberLike), toString(js.NumberLike, Object), NumberLike.toFixed(Object)

toPrecision

public static final java.lang.String toPrecision(NumberLike<?> n)

Converts the current number to a string.

This method simply calls NumberLike.toString() to convert the number to a base-10 value.

Parameters:
n - The current number.
Returns:
A string representation of the current number. The number is rounded or padded with zeros as necessary.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked on an instance that is not a number. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:

toPrecision

public static final java.lang.String toPrecision(NumberLike<?> n,
                                                 java.lang.Object precision)

Converts the current number to a string using the specified number of significant digits. Uses exponential or fixed-point notation depending on the size of the number and the number of significant digits specified.

Parameters:
n - The current number.
precision - The number of significant digits to appear in the returned string. This may be a value between 1 and 21, inclusive. Implementations are allowed to optionally support larger and smaller values of precision. If this argument is undefined, the Object.toString() method is used instead to convert the number to a base-10 value.
Returns:
A string representation of the current number that contains precision significant digits. If precision is large enough to include all the digits of the integer part of the number, the returned string uses fixed-point notation. Otherwise, exponential notation is used with one digit before the decimal place and precision - 1 digits after the decimal place. The number is rounded or padded with zeros as necessary.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a RangeError if digits is too small or too large. See Js.err(Object) and JsRangeError for JS Simulation. Values between 1 and 20, inclusive, will not cause a RangeError. Implementations are allowed to support larger and smaller values as well.
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked on an instance that is not a number. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
toPrecision(js.NumberLike), toExponential(js.NumberLike), toExponential(js.NumberLike, Object), toFixed(js.NumberLike), toFixed(js.NumberLike, Object), toLocaleString(js.NumberLike), toString(js.NumberLike), toString(js.NumberLike, Object), NumberLike.toPrecision(Object)

                                                 java.lang.Object precision)

Implementations are allowed to optionally support larger and smaller values of precision. If this argument is undefined, the Object.toString() method is used instead to convert the number to a base-10 value.
Returns:
A string representation of the current number that contains precision significant digits. If precision is large enough to include all the digits of the integer part of the number, the returned string uses fixed-point notation. Otherwise, exponential notation is used with one digit before the decimal place and precision - 1 digits after the decimal place. The number is rounded or padded with zeros as necessary.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a RangeError if digits is too small or too large. See Js.err(Object) and JsRangeError for JS Simulation. Values between 1 and 20, inclusive, will not cause a RangeError. Implementations are allowed to support larger and smaller values as well.

toLocaleString

public static final java.lang.String toLocaleString(NumberLike<?> n)

Converts the current number to a string using local number-formatting conventions.

Parameters:
n - The current number.
Returns:
An implementation-dependent string representation of the current number, formatted according to local conventions, which may affect such things as the punctuation characters used for the decimal point and the thousands separator.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked on an instance that is not a number. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:

toString

public static final java.lang.String toString(NumberLike<?> n,
                                              java.lang.Object radix)

Converts the current number to a string. When the radix argument is undefined or is specified as 10, the number is converted to a base-10 string.

Although the ECMAScript specification does not require implementations to honor any other values for radix, all implementations in common use accept values between 2 and 36.

Parameters:
n - The current number.
radix - An optional argument that specifies the radix, or base, between 2 and 36, in which the number should be represented. If undefined, base 10 is used. Note, however, that the ECMAScript specification allows an implementation to return any value if this argument is specified as any value other than 10.
Returns:
A string representation of the current number, in the specified base.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked on an instance that is not a number. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
toString(js.NumberLike), toExponential(js.NumberLike), toExponential(js.NumberLike, Object), toFixed(js.NumberLike), toFixed(js.NumberLike, Object), toPrecision(js.NumberLike), toPrecision(js.NumberLike, Object), toLocaleString(js.NumberLike), NumberLike.toString(Object)

toString

public static final java.lang.String toString(java.lang.Number n,
                                              java.lang.Object radix)

Converts the current number to a string. When the radix argument is undefined or is specified as 10, the number is converted to a base-10 string.

Although the ECMAScript specification does not require implementations to honor any other values for radix, all implementations in common use accept values between 2 and 36.

Parameters:
n - The current number.
radix - An optional argument that specifies the radix, or base, between 2 and 36, in which the number should be represented. If undefined, base 10 is used. Note, however, that the ECMAScript specification allows an implementation to return any value if this argument is specified as any value other than 10.
Returns:
A string representation of the current number, in the specified base.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked on an instance that is not a number. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
